awd_titl_txt: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Learn-and-Adapt to Manage Dynamic Cyber-Physical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates algorithmic innovations targeting the cyber-physical system (CPS) opportunities emerging from cloud, transportation, and power networks. The envisioned advances pertain to models and algorithms for learn-and-adapt approaches to managing CPS; online data-driven workload balancing for sustainable data center networks; real-time traffic management for transportation networks in smart cities; and learning-aided online decentralized energy management for smart power networks.

The proposed research has great potential for social, environmental, and economic benefits, as it directly impacts the wireless Internet, scalable cloud networks, intelligent transportation, and microgrids supporting smart homes and cars. Cloud users' experience can be enhanced with markedly low request delay. Smart cars can end up consuming less fuel, and experience less waiting time at road intersections due to efficient signal control and vehicle routing. Finally, power grid operators can benefit from relaxed battery capacity requirements and fast electric vehicle charging at substations. Broader transformative impact will be effected by reaching out to middle-school students and the community, involving undergraduates in research, increasing participation of under-represented minorities, and promoting a scientifically literate public.

por.por_cntn:
Use of Generalized Correntropy as a Machine Learning Tool for Cyber-Physical Systems in Non-Gaussian Environments

 

Statistical and machine learning schemes used in cyber-physical systems (CPS) to integrate physical and engineered processes are usually optimized for Gaussian noise backgrounds based on smooth, convex, mathematically tractable, minimum mean square (MSE) cost functions. Information theory-based cost functions use correntropy, which generalizes the MSE cost function, and has been shown to be effective for adaptive filter and machine learning algorithm designs.  However, such schemes are susceptible to outliers in the data and usually perform poorly when the data exhibits non-Gaussian characteristics.  Many cyber-physical systems operate in non-Gaussian and impulsive noise environments, for which the Gaussian kernel can be generalized. The resulting generalized Gaussian correntropy induced cost function has been shown to perform well for classification applications in a non-Gaussian environment that is modeled by a mixture of two Gaussian distributions. In this work, we conducted performance studies of the generalized correntropy induced cost function as a machine learning tool for classification in a cyber-physical system in non-Gaussian environments by considering two more general non-Gaussian noise models, namely, the generalized Gaussian distribution (which includes the Laplace, Gaussian, and uniform distributions as special cases) and the generalized Cauchy distribution. Furthermore, the addition of the logarithmic function can significantly improve the robustness of the system by significantly increasing the correntropy bandwidth. This improvement is much more noticeable when in a generalized Gaussian noise environment than in a generalized Cauchy noise environment. For a fixed set of generalized Gaussian correntropy parameters, the machine learning schemes perform better (based on the key classification metrics) in generalized Gaussian noise than in generalized Cauchy noise.
